componenttext: Ken, I think the consensus is around $4 that you will begin to see more equipment go into gas formations looking for gas at the $4 level. I think that’s the best consensus view I can give you.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Barnes from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Barnes from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on the coastal side. You’ve elaborated a couple of times about the changes in the New York Harbor market and specifically relocating some equipment out of there. I go back and think about during the downturn, Kirby took this leader
componenttext: Just a quick question on the coastal side. You’ve elaborated a couple of times about the changes in the New York Harbor market and specifically relocating some equipment out of there. I go back and think about during the downturn, Kirby took this leadership position on the inland barge side, kind of cut the industry rational as a whole by doing some things with your fleet, maybe taking some retirements early and that kind of thing. I am just kind of curious as to how you feel about the current size of your coastal business and how close you think you are from a size perspective, to being able to kind of influence that same behavior on the coast-wise business as you were able to on the inland side?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I am not sure that you ever truly influence it. But what we’re able to do that Kirby uniquely can do is take barges that will fit in inland service and move them into that service. I think with respect to the coastal trade, doing much more of that
componenttext: Yes, I am not sure that you ever truly influence it. But what we’re able to do that Kirby uniquely can do is take barges that will fit in inland service and move them into that service. I think with respect to the coastal trade, doing much more of that would be giving up the opportunities going forward because we see that business moving to balance. It’s slow but it's steady. You see the equipment being, in some cases, shifted to really a new product, the movement of crude oil. And with any reasonable increase in the economy you’re going to stimulate more gasoline movements. So I don't think the industry is that far from balance. On the inland business, we had in 2008 going into the recession, a fleet that was older than our coastal fleet, and we used the opportunity of reduced demand as an opportunity to take barges kind of out of service, that frankly should have been taken out probably a couple years before. But demand was such that we needed them and embarked on a replacement program at very attractive prices that drove down the age of the fleet. And as Greg explained, it significantly increased our reliability with the newer equipment. So it was a little different, I think, scenario on the inland side than on the coastal side right now.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: All right, that makes sense. In terms of the low water conditions that impacted the inland side, this is the first time I can recall where you had this severe a situation for an entire quarter, where it kind of impacted you for the entirety of the quarter
componenttext: All right, that makes sense. In terms of the low water conditions that impacted the inland side, this is the first time I can recall where you had this severe a situation for an entire quarter, where it kind of impacted you for the entirety of the quarter. I am just kind of curious, as you look back at the third quarter, that low river condition, light loading, that type of thing, if you hadn’t had those conditions exist, would your utilization levels have been as strong and do you think your pricing would have been as strong versus if you had kind of a normal river condition situation?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: That’s a good question. Most of the additional capacity needed to service upriver customers is 10,000 barrel capacity. And most of that frankly is contracted, so you don’t see it in spot rates. It just takes more equipment to service the contracted bu
componenttext: That’s a good question. Most of the additional capacity needed to service upriver customers is 10,000 barrel capacity. And most of that frankly is contracted, so you don’t see it in spot rates. It just takes more equipment to service the contracted business that you have. The 30,000 barrel fleet, for the most part, is a lower river Gulf of Mexico fleet. Now there are some exceptions. There is some crude oil now being moved out of St. Louis, which is new. And there are some unit tows that operate, but the bulk of the 30,000 barrel fleet is a lower river canal-based fleet. And that would have been unaffected really by low water conditions and I think that the utilization which drove, I think, the pricing increases that we and others saw was just real demand that was being handled by that fleet.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then can I just ask one question on CapEx, kind of 2. First, the CapEx numbers that you gave in the press release, there was no real mention about the CapEx dollar spend into the diesel engine business. Can you give us some color there? And then secon
componenttext: And then can I just ask one question on CapEx, kind of 2. First, the CapEx numbers that you gave in the press release, there was no real mention about the CapEx dollar spend into the diesel engine business. Can you give us some color there? And then secondly, on CapEx, do you have any preliminary guidance you can give us around 2013 CapEx?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: We did spend a little bit in the diesel business to buy off a lease, one of our properties in Oklahoma City. But the capital spending in the diesel business is pretty minimal. Most of our spending is in the marine side, as you might imagine, and gets to t
componenttext: We did spend a little bit in the diesel business to buy off a lease, one of our properties in Oklahoma City. But the capital spending in the diesel business is pretty minimal. Most of our spending is in the marine side, as you might imagine, and gets to the fleet replacement that we've had going on for several years and it continues. And this would probably be our big year. Next year we haven’t given official guidance, but it could be in the order of $150 million to $200 million, depending on what we do in the inland space. But that will be down, obviously, from this year for around $300 million or little above $300 million. So -- but as you would expect, John, it’s marine driven.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I'm assuming that $150 million to $200 million is based on the continuation of current conditions and not some material move up in the economy?
componenttext: Okay. And I'm assuming that $150 million to $200 million is based on the continuation of current conditions and not some material move up in the economy?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chaz Jones from Wunderlich.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chaz Jones from Wunderlich.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just first off, does the Dow Chemical announcement earlier this week have any impact whatsoever on your business?
componenttext: Just first off, does the Dow Chemical announcement earlier this week have any impact whatsoever on your business?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Chaz, it’s Greg. It really does not. What Dow was talking about there was really European and Asian production areas. So it really doesn’t impact our area at all. In fact, we've seen some of the players in the chemical space that have pending capital
componenttext: Chaz, it’s Greg. It really does not. What Dow was talking about there was really European and Asian production areas. So it really doesn’t impact our area at all. In fact, we've seen some of the players in the chemical space that have pending capital projects that have reiterated their plans to go forward with those, as late as this morning. So we continue to be encouraged by the interest in investment in the petrochemical complex in the U.S. Gulf.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then to follow up on United, the 8.5% margin, just from your comments, that it sounds like that’s probably bottoming out and as we think about 2013, are you saying that just from a modeling standpoint engine services revenues are probably down year-
componenttext: And then to follow up on United, the 8.5% margin, just from your comments, that it sounds like that’s probably bottoming out and as we think about 2013, are you saying that just from a modeling standpoint engine services revenues are probably down year-over-year, but margins are up because of that mix shift that United -- but potentially overall operating profits are down?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think directionally that's right. I don’t want to comment prematurely on what 2013 is going to look like. But I think directionally, that’s about right.
componenttext: I think directionally that's right. I don’t want to comment prematurely on what 2013 is going to look like. But I think directionally, that’s about right.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012

componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Sterling from BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: You guys have talked about Kirby Offshore Marine, your utilization just under 80%. Realistically where do you think this utilization can go in light of maybe little bit of tick up we’ve seen in improvement with some crude oil movement and improvement in
componenttext: You guys have talked about Kirby Offshore Marine, your utilization just under 80%. Realistically where do you think this utilization can go in light of maybe little bit of tick up we’ve seen in improvement with some crude oil movement and improvement in East to West. I imagine it can’t be as size your core business in the low to mid-90s. But how should we think about utilization as it continues to improve in offshore?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think you should think of it actually fairly similar to the inland business. You could get into the 90% to 95%, you will never get above 95%. It's just -- there is inefficiencies that happen. The question is how long does it take to get that utilization
componenttext: I think you should think of it actually fairly similar to the inland business. You could get into the 90% to 95%, you will never get above 95%. It's just -- there is inefficiencies that happen. The question is how long does it take to get that utilization up? We continue -- as I mentioned earlier we continue to see older equipment retired. We moved some equipment out of the market. So that’s helping but clearly the crude demand is absorbing some capacity and driving up industry utilization. We are seeing regional periods of high utilization but then it will turn back down a little bit. So that the economy could help a lot as Joe indicated but a little bit of economic strength and discontinued crude movement situation could start push utilization up fairly healthy next year and maybe we get into the mid maybe even high 80s. We will have to see how it develops.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: So Dave, where is [indiscernible] for utilization for you guys to really push pricing, is it 80%, 85%?
componenttext: So Dave, where is [indiscernible] for utilization for you guys to really push pricing, is it 80%, 85%?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it’s 85%. As I said, we got a little bit of pricing this quarter but it was in a regional kind of context. You need, very similar to inland, you need that sustained above 85% and you could get it earlier than that if the market really thinks that i
componenttext: Yes, it’s 85%. As I said, we got a little bit of pricing this quarter but it was in a regional kind of context. You need, very similar to inland, you need that sustained above 85% and you could get it earlier than that if the market really thinks that it’s going to get a lot tighter. It’s not only the absolute level of utilization, it’s about what the customers thinks going to happen right. If they look forward and they say, "Oh, my goodness, it’s going to be harder to get a barge," then we can push pricing a little earlier. But 85% really is kind of that magic line.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And along those lines too, you talked about customer behavior in the offshore market, but remind me there’s still some single hull capacity in the offshore market that’s got to come out. So could you remind me how much single hull capacity there is an
componenttext: And along those lines too, you talked about customer behavior in the offshore market, but remind me there’s still some single hull capacity in the offshore market that’s got to come out. So could you remind me how much single hull capacity there is and when that has to come out by? And I imagine that if the economy picks up and starts moving more gas and what have you, and the customer sees some single hull capacity kind of exit the market, is that -- that’s got to be favorable for your business.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, believe the single skin was about 8%. I think that's been coming down. We haven’t done -- there is no industry survey, so we kind of got to go through Coast Guard databases to get it. But it’s probably and still in that order of magnitude, maybe
componenttext: Yes, believe the single skin was about 8%. I think that's been coming down. We haven’t done -- there is no industry survey, so we kind of got to go through Coast Guard databases to get it. But it’s probably and still in that order of magnitude, maybe 5% to 8%. But it will be coming down, and it has to be out by the end of 2014.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alex Brand from SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alex Brand from SunTrust.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don’t remember in the time I’ve covered you that you ever had water conditions be this kind of persistent impact, and I think you said they might actually get worse. So when we look at Q3 and you say 3 to 4 was water conditions and weather. How much
componenttext: I don’t remember in the time I’ve covered you that you ever had water conditions be this kind of persistent impact, and I think you said they might actually get worse. So when we look at Q3 and you say 3 to 4 was water conditions and weather. How much of that's really water conditions? I mean is it $0.03, or $0.04, or $0.05 cents impact to the fourth quarter that you're thinking about, or what?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was $0.03 to $0.04 water and hurricane. And it’s about $0.01 to $0.02 -- $0.015 to $0.02 on hurricane and that would be $0.02 to $0.03 water, I guess.
componenttext: Yes, it was $0.03 to $0.04 water and hurricane. And it’s about $0.01 to $0.02 -- $0.015 to $0.02 on hurricane and that would be $0.02 to $0.03 water, I guess.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then at some point here in the fourth quarter you expect the upper part of the river to kind of close anyway, right? So it really doesn't impact at some point late in the fourth quarter and into the first quarter, is that the right way to think about
componenttext: And then at some point here in the fourth quarter you expect the upper part of the river to kind of close anyway, right? So it really doesn't impact at some point late in the fourth quarter and into the first quarter, is that the right way to think about that?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, because -- unfortunately you have to get on the section that is going to be most affected to get into the Illinois River which typically does remain open. The upper Mississippi River north of St. Louis, you want to be off that river by around Thanksgi
componenttext: No, because -- unfortunately you have to get on the section that is going to be most affected to get into the Illinois River which typically does remain open. The upper Mississippi River north of St. Louis, you want to be off that river by around Thanksgiving, because it does freeze. But the Illinois typically either -- that either doesn’t freeze or it freezes so that you can actually break the ice and get to ports south of Chicago. So that’s an active river. We’re not saying that it’s going to close. We’re just putting a marker down that we are watching it carefully, but that stretch of the river is dependent on flows coming out of the Missouri River. The Corps typically reduces those flows beginning in November, and that is a potential problem. Now there are a number of things that can be done, and I think that industry and the Corps are looking at all of them. But it would all go away if it would just rain. And this is typically the time of the year frankly that it begins to rain. So we’ll just have to monitor it.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: With respect to United, I sense maybe a little less optimism about the speed of the ramp up in re-man than I think I was hearing in the past. And I am wondering if that's just a function of -- it’s been harder to get it going than you thought, and reall
componenttext: With respect to United, I sense maybe a little less optimism about the speed of the ramp up in re-man than I think I was hearing in the past. And I am wondering if that's just a function of -- it’s been harder to get it going than you thought, and really what I'm thinking about is when we look at next year, I thought the idea was re-man is lower revenue but higher margin and so you don't lose too much profitability. But I am wondering if that's changed and when do we really lap those manufacturing comps that, that could -- that re-man could make up the slack?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: That’s the question. Re-man is making progress, there are just a lot of moving parts in it to make it an efficient process. And as Greg mentioned, we’re working with a consultant to help us there. I think that, that’s going to be very positive. The
componenttext: That’s the question. Re-man is making progress, there are just a lot of moving parts in it to make it an efficient process. And as Greg mentioned, we’re working with a consultant to help us there. I think that, that’s going to be very positive. The other issue is how much and -- we’re not ready to talk about this yet, but that it’s something that you should ask us about certainly in January, is how much can you push through the current facility without investing new capital? And that really is our focus, making it efficient and then pushing as much as you can through current facilities without investing capital. We can invest the capital. We have positioned ourselves to add to the facility that we have by buying the adjacent property and actually taking that property that was leased and buying it. But our first effort is to maximize the capacity that we have and then to add capacity once we've done that. And I think we will have a much better feeling for all of that by the first of next year.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Beard from Iberia.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Beard from Iberia.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Could you elaborate a little bit about the outlook for the overall inland barge fleet growth for this year and any thoughts on next year?
componenttext: Could you elaborate a little bit about the outlook for the overall inland barge fleet growth for this year and any thoughts on next year?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, we think that there is going to be another approximately 200 barges built, a combination of 30,000 and 10,000 barrel barges. And that again, we think that some of that’s going to be replacement, most of our building program is replacement. And that
componenttext: Yes, we think that there is going to be another approximately 200 barges built, a combination of 30,000 and 10,000 barrel barges. And that again, we think that some of that’s going to be replacement, most of our building program is replacement. And that the industry continues to need capacity to service new requirements, particularly their black oil requirements, crude oil requirements. Is that what you wanted?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, and then would you say the 200, is that for this year or are you speculating out in ’13?
componenttext: Yes, and then would you say the 200, is that for this year or are you speculating out in ’13?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, that’s a 2013 number, this year it’s actually little more. Remember you get the tax benefits issue.
componenttext: No, that’s a 2013 number, this year it’s actually little more. Remember you get the tax benefits issue.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then as it relates to the coastal market in general, with utilization picking up, has that changed the outlook for acquisitions in that area or prices for fleets or hasn’t changed the big picture?
componenttext: And then as it relates to the coastal market in general, with utilization picking up, has that changed the outlook for acquisitions in that area or prices for fleets or hasn’t changed the big picture?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: The acquisition environment is still okay in the coastwise and -- but it could start impacting the price expectations of potential sellers. I think there is a couple things going on -- still going on. People are still recovering from what was pretty rough
componenttext: The acquisition environment is still okay in the coastwise and -- but it could start impacting the price expectations of potential sellers. I think there is a couple things going on -- still going on. People are still recovering from what was pretty rough time in the coastwise business. And they’re making a little money and they are looking at their succession plans and saying, "Well, still let’s get out." But you're right, if the outlook continues to brighten, it may close the window for further consolidation for a while in the coastwise. But it still looks pretty good right now. I don’t want to be too dour, too negative about that.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jon Tomopolous [ph] from Argus [ph].
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jon Tomopolous [ph] from Argus [ph].

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just wondering first of all, about the ATB space. Do you see any kind of opportunity for Kirby there in terms of acquisitions and kind of synergies with your existing fleet. I guess I am kind of thinking that maybe about the OSG fleets, those guys have be
componenttext: Just wondering first of all, about the ATB space. Do you see any kind of opportunity for Kirby there in terms of acquisitions and kind of synergies with your existing fleet. I guess I am kind of thinking that maybe about the OSG fleets, those guys have been in difficulties lately. Is the ATB something you’re interested in?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: We already operate ATB. So the bulk of -- in fact, the bulk of the comp fleet is ATB. ATB is an articulated tug barge unit where the tug locks into the notch of the barge but stays independently bland [ph] and a lot of our equipment is there. The OSG flee
componenttext: We already operate ATB. So the bulk of -- in fact, the bulk of the comp fleet is ATB. ATB is an articulated tug barge unit where the tug locks into the notch of the barge but stays independently bland [ph] and a lot of our equipment is there. The OSG fleet, we are certainly watching it. I don’t -- it's a complicated situation. They have equipment that -- they control equipment that certainly is very attractive. But some of it they don’t own, some of it is ineligible for the Coast Guard -- coastwise Jones Act trade and some of it pretty old. As with anything, it depends on the deal, whether you get excited or not, and I think that time just needs to sort out what OSG is going to do. My understanding just reading the press clips, is that they have hired somebody to help them do that.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And just going back to the -- I guess that kind of relates from my kind of view of things to crude movements. I know some of their bigger barges are interesting for moving to crude up from Gulf Coast to the Northeast. Do you see demand for crude exports f
componenttext: And just going back to the -- I guess that kind of relates from my kind of view of things to crude movements. I know some of their bigger barges are interesting for moving to crude up from Gulf Coast to the Northeast. Do you see demand for crude exports from any other Gulf Coast terminals, you mentioned Corpus Christi earlier, and do you see that demand kind of improving in 2013?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, and really there is 2 kinds of demand. There is demand that goes into -- that is best suited for barges that are similar to what com operates which is kind of 150 and below, sweet spot probably 80,000 to 120,000 barrels. And then there is demand that
componenttext: Yes, and really there is 2 kinds of demand. There is demand that goes into -- that is best suited for barges that are similar to what com operates which is kind of 150 and below, sweet spot probably 80,000 to 120,000 barrels. And then there is demand that is -- that has a longer supply chain, which an OSG ship or a larger barge would be better suited for. And that would be South Texas to the East Coast. The sweet spot for us is the shorter trip kind of demand. With respect to OSG, there are couple of those barges -- large barges are not eligible for that trade. They were built with construction subsidized funds and they are not Jones Act eligible.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: One final thing, the crude that -- the barges that you are using to shuttle crude around the U.S. Gulf, is most of that being done on a term basis or are there spot deals going on?
componenttext: One final thing, the crude that -- the barges that you are using to shuttle crude around the U.S. Gulf, is most of that being done on a term basis or are there spot deals going on?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: We would say it’s more spot but clearly some of the operators are now looking for longer term deals. So it’s an evolving market. This is just really starting to take off.
componenttext: We would say it’s more spot but clearly some of the operators are now looking for longer term deals. So it’s an evolving market. This is just really starting to take off.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jimmy Gibert from Iberia Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jimmy Gibert from Iberia Capital.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think maybe some people have, when you talk about low water conditions persisting into part of Q4. Isn't October typically the lowest water levels -- isn't that the month that you find the lowest water levels typically on the Mississippi?
componenttext: I think maybe some people have, when you talk about low water conditions persisting into part of Q4. Isn't October typically the lowest water levels -- isn't that the month that you find the lowest water levels typically on the Mississippi?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: It can be anywhere from about August to October. It will vary year for year -- year-to-year. But yes, it's in this area.
componenttext: It can be anywhere from about August to October. It will vary year for year -- year-to-year. But yes, it's in this area.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then I wanted to kind of follow up like on David’s question about the new builds and retirements. What if I were to call jet boat [ph] or turning marine [ph] and wanted to order a tank barge either a 10 or a 30, what would be the first delivery date
componenttext: And then I wanted to kind of follow up like on David’s question about the new builds and retirements. What if I were to call jet boat [ph] or turning marine [ph] and wanted to order a tank barge either a 10 or a 30, what would be the first delivery date they could get one to me? Assuming I have the financing which I don’t?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Assuming you have the money, the major yards are really pretty booked up through 2013. So it would be the tail end of 2013, maybe first part of 2014, before you'd to be able to get anything from the major yards. There are some specialty yards that aren’
componenttext: Assuming you have the money, the major yards are really pretty booked up through 2013. So it would be the tail end of 2013, maybe first part of 2014, before you'd to be able to get anything from the major yards. There are some specialty yards that aren’t as efficient as those major yards that may be priced slightly higher, that may have some availability for very limited run in production. I am not sure we have the traditional visibility on the jet boat [ph] that we have always had. So they may have some capacity but they seem to be very disciplined with respect to how they are using their capacity.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And just real quick one more, you guys talked about some West Coast movements of crude, and I don’t really understand the West Coast inland barge movement, would that -- would those be coastwise movements and how would that work?
componenttext: And just real quick one more, you guys talked about some West Coast movements of crude, and I don’t really understand the West Coast inland barge movement, would that -- would those be coastwise movements and how would that work?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: They’d be coastwise out of Anacortes up in Washington state, they would come down into maybe the California refineries. And it would just be coastwise of larger barge type movement, 80,000 to 150,000 barrels and maybe, if the volumes are enough, the lar
componenttext: They’d be coastwise out of Anacortes up in Washington state, they would come down into maybe the California refineries. And it would just be coastwise of larger barge type movement, 80,000 to 150,000 barrels and maybe, if the volumes are enough, the larger units, the 330,000 barrel units, which is a space we don’t play in. But clearly the initial volumes would probably be in smaller units, I would imagine. But that again, is just starting to be discussed and it hasn’t really developed yet.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And larger movements, like 300,000 barrels, that would be almost -- is that -- that would be a product tanker almost, would it?
componenttext: And larger movements, like 300,000 barrels, that would be almost -- is that -- that would be a product tanker almost, would it?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Similar. There are some large ATBs that are of that size, like Crowley and some others operating.
componenttext: Similar. There are some large ATBs that are of that size, like Crowley and some others operating.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from Bill Baldwin from Baldwin Anthony.
componenttext: Our last question comes from Bill Baldwin from Baldwin Anthony.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: David, just a quick one here. Are you having any progress on extending out the contracts on KLM [ph]? I know you want to get a little bit more contract in there, and a little less spot. Has that process begun?
componenttext: David, just a quick one here. Are you having any progress on extending out the contracts on KLM [ph]? I know you want to get a little bit more contract in there, and a little less spot. Has that process begun?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: It has and it’s a slow process. We just, I don't want to give the customer name, but we just signed a longer-term deal on the West Coast that’s out 6 years. So a pretty good piece of business for us, so we are very excited to do. But as Joe mentioned,
componenttext: It has and it’s a slow process. We just, I don't want to give the customer name, but we just signed a longer-term deal on the West Coast that’s out 6 years. So a pretty good piece of business for us, so we are very excited to do. But as Joe mentioned, we are also working with some of our inland customers and looking at some of the major carriers that are going to have the volumes year in and year out, which is what we like. And as we've improved the equipment, we are working on vetting with some of these potential major customers. And it’s a process but we are clearly focused on getting some of this equipment termed out a little longer with some more ratable volumes that will be there year in and year out.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Is your target there around 75%, 80% on contract, David, or...
componenttext: Is your target there around 75%, 80% on contract, David, or...

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Quite frankly I like to be above 80% on contract. But it’s going to take time for us to get there.
componenttext: Quite frankly I like to be above 80% on contract. But it’s going to take time for us to get there.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: So this would be more of a contract, longer term contract type business than really than the inland business?
componenttext: So this would be more of a contract, longer term contract type business than really than the inland business?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: We like it to be, yes.
componenttext: We like it to be, yes.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: We certainly appreciate your interest in Kirby Corporation and participating in our call. If you have additional questions or comments, please give me a call. My direct dial number is (713) 435-1135 and we wish you a good day.
componenttext: We certainly appreciate your interest in Kirby Corporation and participating in our call. If you have additional questions or comments, please give me a call. My direct dial number is (713) 435-1135 and we wish you a good day.
